author: Editor
title: Have tofu, will travel: Best cruises for vegans
text:
Posted on August 19, 2015 by Editor 
When it comes to feeding those who have given up all animal products in favor of a vegan lifestyle, cruise lines are surprisingly well prepared to take on the task. 
Cruise ship restaurant menus in most cases feature at least a few vegetarian items, which may or may not be vegan. But chefs are generally prepared to whip up vegan recipes – often really, really good vegan recipes. Buffets feature spreads of fresh salads including creative concoctions involving legumes, there’s fresh fruit galore and rice and stir-fry have practically become a cruise ship staple. You may even find dairy-free ice cream. 
As with any dietary requests, it’s best to alert the cruise line in advance of your specific needs – or have your travel agent make the call. You’ll also want to make contact with the restaurant staff when you get onboard to make sure they got the message. Vegan theme cruises, meanwhile, guarantee you will have plenty of choices, with kitchens switching to a vegan focus. 
Here are the best cruise lines for vegans. 
Regent Seven Seas Cruises, Oceania Cruises: These sister lines offer an entire Vegan Menu with breakfast, lunch and dinner selections. It works in a seven-day cycle for breakfast and a 14-day cycle for lunch (with four courses available) and dinner (with five courses). You might, for example, start the day with vegan “eggs” benedict, chow down at lunch on an Indonesian vegetable stew and indulge in a dinner of vegan protein with turmeric and vegetable curry, followed by vegan strawberry shortcake. The lines also have vegan cookies, ice cream and tea time selections. 
SeaDream Yacht Club: Try the Blood Apple Blaster (apple, ginger, red beet, lime juice and agave) and the Asian Cashew Curry Salad, and don’t miss the Cashew Lemon “Cheesecake.” This small ship line offers the only “raw food” or “living food” menu at sea. Created in conjunction with the Hippocrates Health Institute, the dishes are prepared with raw, organic and vegan ingredients, none of which are heated above 118 degrees Fahrenheit. 
Holland America Line: HAL’s vegetarian menu specifically designates vegan selections, with several choices for each course. For instance, you might do a vegetable Meze Plate with baba ghanoush, chickpea hummus, stuffed grape leaves and tabbouleh salad, served with warm pita; roasted butternut squash soup; and an entrée of Pad Thai noodles. 
Disney Cruise Line: Disney prides itself on meeting special dietary requests. Vegan meals are available at full-service, sit-down restaurants on all the Disney Cruise Line ships – including the adults-only specialty restaurants Palo and Remy. In addition to letting the cruise line know you want vegan cuisine in advance of your cruise, Disney suggests you alert the head server prior to ordering each meal onboard. 
Silversea Cruises: The luxury line goes with a personalized approach to addressing specific vegan requirements – whether religious, holistic, Ayurvedic or Raw. Guests are asked to advise the line of their vegan dietary needs several months in advance. Once onboard, you meet with the executive chef, who will custom-create a menu for your voyage. 
Princess Cruises: Vegetarian items are designated with a “V” on dining room menus and at the buffet. This doesn’t necessarily mean they are vegan, but the line says some items can be modified to vegan on request. Tofu, egg-free pasta and vegetarian burgers are available onboard and can be prepared in a variety of styles. 
Holistic Holiday at Sea: This annual cruise, hosted by natural foods expert Sandy Pukel, sets sail on the MSC Divina from Miami, February 27, 2016. The one-week sailing visits St. Thomas, San Juan and Nassau. Onboard, dozens of top-notch health and wellness experts will talk food, philosophy, meditation, holistic healing, yoga and other topics. Cuisine, prepared under the supervision of internationally known natural food chef Mark Hanna, will be will be non-dairy, vegan/natural and organic-focused. atasteofhealth.org 
Vegan Alaska Cruise: Vegan Vacation with Cruise Planners is hosting a cruise on Holland America Line’s Westerdam, September 19 to 26, round-trip from Seattle. The sailing will visit Juneau, Sitka, Ketchikan and Victoria (B.C.) and includes glacier viewing in Glacier Bay. Well-known vegan chefs will be onboard lecturing and there will be special vegan shore excursions – including a vegan high tea at the Empress Hotel in Victoria. vegancruiseplanners.com 
Vegan River Cruises: This German company specializes in river cruises for vegans. The next sailing is a six-day cruise on the Danube, from Passau to Budapest. The ship embarks December 28, on the Scenic Crystal. Included is a New Year’s party while the ship is docked in Vienna. Vegan cuisine will be offered at all the ship’s restaurants and at high tea, there will be vegan cocktails (drinks are included) and vegan toiletries. Vegan lifestyle immersion will include lectures and workshops. veganrivercruises.com
